commentBody:
A puzzle dedicated to Mean Old Lady!

Way to go, Joe.
The NSC/CANO cross was a bit jarring and took about a minute and a half of the eight minute solve. Rest of it was lovely.
This was a fun one. Loving the baseball themed answers. Baseball's back baby

A nice quick Wednesday.  My great grandmother, grandmother, wife and daughter are all quilters so I had the theme covered.  Other than trying LSD before LEG, I didn‚Äôt hit any snags.

I was delighted to see EMILE Hirsch in the puzzle.  I enjoyed his performance in Into The Wild based on Jon Krakauer‚Äôs excellent book
Went awry by initially entering the wrong Stephen with a three letter surname from V for Vendetta!
Pretty easy for a Wednesday.

As a golf fan, it's funny that PAR is almost never clued accurately for the game.  (Average score of all golfers is something like 20 to 30 *over par* for an 18 hole round).  Neither I, nor anyone I've ever played with, *expects* it!  Yet LIE is clued here perfectly.

A QUILTING BEE is a normally a gathering of quilters working on ONE quilt stretched on a quilt frame. 

L

Oh.  This was okay.  I was going to complain the theme wasn't Thursday quality and then I checked the date again.  ;)

Still I'm really not fond of the "block" answer - mostly because I'd never heard of a quilting block and it sounds a little generic (border does too), but in the end just something new to me.

A cromulent puzzle overall.  Sky Mall and destination of a walk were cute.  (Huh, cromulent made it into Merriam Webster in 2023.  That takes the fun out of using it.)

I learned more about quilting tonight than I ever expected to in my lifetime. Some great cluing: FIRST, ALIAS, AS ONE, SKYMALL, LIE. 

PAR felt like an insult, though. Oh sure, I totally might expect to PAR‚Ä¶if I‚Äôm playing disc golf.
I had WORM before BITE which is also good for m angler but bad for a dog trainer

Crossword Revolution Day 29: BORDER TERRIER Terriers don‚Äôt give up easily. https://www.nbcnews.com/nightly-news/video/escaping-dog-brings-new-orleans-community-together-232130117628 Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢.

When she does the puzzle in the morning, my mother will enjoy the baseball and quilting references even more than I did!
She‚Äôll likely have to rely on crossings for TAYTAY, a clue the six-year-old in my house would joyfully have offered. In fact, @Sam, in answer to your question, the nickname is so widely used that Siri will play her music prompted by it.

BLOCKBUSTER:

You put two purple pieces together instead of purple and blue.

Somehow one piece went in wrong side up.

The corners just are so so sloppy.

Sigh: you just have to bust that block up and do it over.

Ivan IV was feeling awful and went to the hospital. Once he was situated in his room, a nurse came. "OK, Mr. Ivan, what feels so terrible?" she said to him jollily. She knew from deep experience how to handle these grumpy types. He wouldn't answer her, but let her fuss over him and tuck a duvet up under his incredibly long beard. "Does that meet with your blanket approval?" she asked, a little joke that usually got at least a feeble grin. This time, nothing, he simply stared straight ahead.

Soon, the new guy came in, the Emile Hersch lookalike, dragging his apparatus, a steampunk coatrack with tubes, wires and bags. "I've an Ivan IV's IV" he said, and giggled. 

The nurse turned the TV on. Taylor Swift was on stage singing loudly and gyrating. Ivan, who had been staring at the poster of Seurat's "Sunday in the Park," which had the effect increasing the pain in his fibula, like being hit with an anvil, turned his attention to the screen. She was singing -- it seemed more like screaming -- fish clenched:

All that bloodshed, crimson clover
Uh-huh, sweet dream was over
My hand was the one you reached for
All throughout the Great War
Always remember
Uh-huh, tears on the letter
I vowed not to cry anymore
If we survived the Great War...

"Kto eto?" Ivan demanded of the nurse, waving at the screen.

"Oh that's Tay Tay, I love her! Especially her Eon tour, like her Era tour times ten, so blockbuster!" On TV the crowd roared the lyrics as one. 

Ivan felt his leg stir like a sea eel.

I used to believe 39D.

No longer.

Meh, I did not enjoy this at all. Wednesday is usually my favorite puzzle of the week, so it was especially unpleasant to experience what I did today.

First, I had no idea what the theme was about. Was it... Quilting? I'm sure somebody found that cute and oh so loved the puzzle - good for them, and I actually mean that. I, however, know no quilting terminology so the only thing the theme did for me was hinder my solve.

Second, the secluded section of the puzzle with the baseballer and some abbreviated organisation crossing was just nasty. At least I got NBC on my own there... I did an alphabet run for NS_ and _ANO when that was my last square left. However, all those letters later I still did not get my happy music. By this time I was so annoyed I just checked the puzzle. It turned out I had another bad square: at the crossing of the actor REo and GASToPS. The latter looked good enough (especially to somebody who has never heard of a GAS TAP), and I didn't know the actor. For an additional level of annoyance: I *did* remember another Stephen from that movie, Fry. But noooo, let's ask about *another* Stephen why don't we...

My final move was to reveal the C of NS_ and _ANO.

Again, meh. Feel free to stone me for my negativity but I have really had a bad time with this puzzle.
not the biggest fan of 10D's clue, feels clunky. I appreciate the parallelism in 36 & 37D, both visually and answer wise!

Straightforward  with the exception of the C in CANO & NSC. 

Puzzled by the photo in Sam‚Äôs column. Did ladies in the monochrome days really hike in heels?

I found this surprisingly easy, granted I start using that Autocheck(?) thing on Wednesdays. I notice a couple of others found the same one hard place I did where 23A and 25D cross, but I did an extremely short alphabet run there and I was finished.

"Want to make another blanket?"
"We should probably quilt while we're ahead."

(Sew much for that pun.)

As someone currently packing for my trip to QuiltCon in Phoenix this week, I very much enjoyed this puzzle! For the complainers, you really didn't have to know anything about quilting to figure out BLOCKBUSTER or the other clues, (e.g. BORDER TERRIER, BATTING PRACTICE). This grid has EIGHT sports related references (not even including CANOE, the hunting reference, and BETting) and a bunch of music, entertainment and geography related answers. This was more like Easter eggs for us quilters and honestly the theme clue didn't help me at all. 

P.S. Always love getting to figure out whether it's INNIE or OUTIE.

As opposed to a LAND EEL???

Otherwise a lovely puzzle. 

And for those not familiar with Robinson Cano, check out his swing on YouTube. Absolutely terrif/FAB

The bottom right section the puzzle was fun and got my hopes up but the rest of it turned to looking up the answers one by one and getting frustrated over the lack of sense. SEA EEL? Really?

This might show my lack of knowledge but what do you mean the destination of a walk is FIRST? Let's take a trip to first? Is it I'm going to take a walk first? Or is it some random obscure tidbit that a handful of people understand?

3/10
Can someone please explain 60D? What does LIE mean that I‚Äôm missing?
I enjoyed this puzzle.    I don't know that I am getting better at solving, but this was relatively easy for me.   No look ups for once.   Haha.

2/19/25

Back to the banks of the Pardon Alice River*

An old Texan hippie
with a peahen and a nene
lived for a while in the Piney Woods

but she suffered from apnea
which she blamed on the trees
until one day she happen(ed) to
have an epiphany:

There‚Äôs probably less pollen
out west on the Pardon Alice!

So the hippie cried ‚ÄúYippee‚Äù
and the birds said ‚ÄúYeah‚Äù
and they all moved to Stonewall
and they‚Äôre still there today.

Words from 2/18: epiphany, hippie, nene, peahen, piney

*See Spelling Bee Forum of 1/24/24 for an earlier reference to the this river. Its real name is Pedernales, usually mispronounced by local anglophones as ‚Äúper-duh-nal-es‚Äù and further corrupted by a TV caption writer as ‚ÄúPardon Alice.‚Äù  Neither that poem nor this one has anything to do with the real river. (Poem in the loose sense; ‚Äúverses‚Äù might be a more accurate term. Or ‚Äúdoggerel,‚Äù but I‚Äôve never liked that word. ‚ÄúCatterel‚Äù?)
The river runs west of Austin. Stonewall is the site of the LBJ Ranch. The Piney Woods are in East Texas and adjacent states. The nene of course is Hawaiian; I have no idea how the Texas hippie aquired one.

Eh. Not too tricky but didn‚Äôt enjoy this at all. Some pretty weird clueing and was just one of those puzzles you trudge your way through. 

Well below average time for a Wednesday, but honestly just a boring puzzle with no real standouts.

Nice puzzle, although it felt way more like a Tuesday-level of difficulty.

Fun and breezy throughout, although I'm not sure I agree with Sam's characterization of TSKTSKED being "delightful." :)

Just right for a Wednesday , with a clever reveal.
  I‚Äôm sure you mother was very pleased with today‚Äôs puzzle, Joe.

Well... fairly smooth Tuesday workout, but must confess that even when I was done I was not entirely grasping how the theme worked. I mean I get the 'B' part, but wasn't really seeing how 'quilting' related to the beginning of each of the theme answers. Well... blanket, sure. But can you quilt a block or a bat? Or was it just the letter B?  Either I'm missing something, or I'm just not entirely catching on to it. Not sure. 

No big deal. A quite wonderful puzzle find today that I'll put in a reply. 

....

I always liked Edmund Burke's quote about EVIL. "The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing."

Unnecessarily gendered, but you get the point.

History is watching.

Strands Thread:


Strands #353
‚ÄúPick your own prefix‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Select no spoilers please until after the View All Replies button.

This was a stumper.

I think a debut by CJ Robinson and Natalie Erjavec.   

Well done.
Spare a thought for us non-American solvers who struggle ardently to keep up with the many US intelligence agencies. NSC, NSA, CIA, DIA, FBI, NRO, DHS... The list goes on.

Lots to look up for me as someone who doesn't know anything about American sports, but that's nice always good to learn. Felt more difficult than it was, coming in surprisingly under my average. Thanks for the nicely tricky Wednesday workout!
One thing: please, never, ever, allow TSK TSK-ED in a crossword ever again! "Delightful" is not the word I uttered when I realised that really was the answer...!

A frustrating solve. Could not understand 1A before reading Wordplay. Of course it‚Äôs a sports thing.

That NBC, NSC, CANO square was hair tuggingly annoying. If you know, you know. If you don‚Äôt. Sheesh.

Got the QUILTING theme, which is cute. More an American hobby I think. 

I‚Äôll take the win on this one. Always impressed by constructor skills, but otherwise a little bland for me. Sorry.

Regarding SEURAT's work, dots all there is.






(Hi Mike from Munster!)
A Monday puzzle for me. I have made quilts, but would never call one a blanket...just saying. A coverlet or a quilt.
As a quilter for 25  years, we take high offense when you call our quilts ‚Äúblankets‚Äù. IYKYK

I guess you‚Äôve got to respect a constructor who puts a big subliminal ad to the editors in a spanner right across their puzzle submission. BLANKET APPROVAL indeed.

(Reading the comments below, looks like the NYTXW is in for a little foreign policy advice. Maybe time to establish a Naticky Stuff Committee?)

Last letter to fall?

C in CANO!
CC now knows!

I know CANO.
*And* NSC.

Will I remember them?
Unlikely.

Thank you Joe!
Happy hump day all!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	I love the cooperative nature of a QUILTING BEE, where a group works together to make a single quilt.  MERGER in the grid struck me as a lovely echo of the theme.
‚Ä¢	Sweet to see FIRST located at 1-across.
‚Ä¢	I smiled when I filled TSK-TSKED in, playful as it is, and, IMO, a more effective verb than simply ‚Äútsked‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	Apt cross of ON AIR and SKY MALL.
‚Ä¢	Beautiful words, INGENUE and REGALING.
‚Ä¢	Is it too soon to give INNIE a ‚ÄúSeverance‚Äù clue?
‚Ä¢	FIBULA and LIE in the box got me thinking.  A fib is typically an unimportant lie; I‚Äôd like to propose FIBULA as being an unimportant fib.

So, Joe, on top of a pleasurable theme, your puzzle tripped off lots of lovely sparks, and set me off into the day in a splendid state of mind. Thank you!

Loved the theme, but maybe that‚Äôs my *bias* as a quilter showing :) Additionally, any reference to my lord and savior at 46D always tickles me. I‚Äôm unfamiliar with Mr. Hirsch, so after the first few crosses I assumed/hoped we shared a name, but alas. 

That middle-left section had me quite stumped - I had bLoB at first, then fLAB and aBC. The only Robinson I knew in baseball was Jackie, and I guess I‚Äôve never thought of 23A in acronym form. Unrelatedly, I initially put down tAx for 1D before realizing that the clue did not actually say ‚Äútariff‚Äù. Oops. 

All in all, a slower than average Wednesday for me, but still fun! Thanks Joe!
1A let me know we were on the same wavelength right off the bat. With spring training just starting, this one was a hit for me‚Äî thanks!
Ivan IV was often called Ivan grozny, which translates loosely to Ivan the Awe-inspiring.

Good morning! 
I'm hoping @Mean Old Lady enjoyed today's theme. I know she's a quilter.
Some day I'd like to see "Actor Stephen.." clued as "Dolours Price spouse, Stephen", or some such.
How many people realllllly wanted "cockadoodledoo" to be a word in today's Spelling Bee?! Me!

Oooooookay.  One of my first entries this morning:  BATTING! And then what to my wondering eyes should appear?  Oh, goodie!  A QUILTING BEE.  How long have we stitchers waited for this happy moment? 
I was solving away, (even willing to overlook the clue calling the *herding* breed--the wonderful BORDER TERRIER--a "Small British *hunting* dog") and I reached 29A ....B...L...A... Say it ain't so, Joe!!!
If I had been wearing pearls, I might have clutched them as I reeled back from the breakfast table.  Even DHubby TSK-TSK-ED.

A QUILT... is... NOT... a... BLANKET.    

No part of a QUILT is ever referred to as a BLANKETY BLANK BLANKET, BUSTER.

Thanks for asking.  Yes, at present I am QUILTING two children's quilts (total of 48 pineapple-variant BLOCKs.)  Two small art quilts await BIINDING.  I am prepping fabric for, well, four other projects.  Don't judge!  It keeps me off the streets and out of the bars, right?

Before anyone jumps on me....yeah, I looked up the TERRIER.
I was thinking of the COLLIE.  Oops.
That should make me more forgiving, right?
As if.

‚ÄúThe answer is SKYMALL, a former in-flight magazine that allowed passengers to purchase products while ‚Äúhigh,‚Äù as in flying. Apropos of nothing, this entry began appearing in the New York Times Crossword just as the magazine was going out of circulation.‚Äù

How is this ‚Äúapropos of nothing‚Äù? It is directly related to the topic being discussed. Not to nitpick, but I feel like the one place I should be able to rely on words being used correctly is a column catering to word nerds in the NYT.

A nice, tidy Wednesday puzzle solved during a bout of insomnia. Doing the puzzles or reading always helps to make me sleepy again. So when I finished the NYT puzzles I pulled up my quilt and went back to sleep.

I‚Äôm not what would be called a Swiftie (although I think she is a very talented songwriter, a hard-working performer, and an all
round admirable person, I am not her target audience), but I have only heard  her called ‚ÄúTayTay‚Äù from the young people in my life, never a single ‚ÄúTay.‚Äù

I enjoyed this but it was a quite long haul.
Obviously, 1A - extensively explained already.
All the initialisms
INT - abbreviation for ....
SICEM and SKYMALL - totally mysterious
All the proper names were unknown to me, and their nicknames.
I assumed a slugger would be a boxer.
BATTING was unknown, we call it wadding.
I remembered about BOSSES in gaming!
As a good European I knew about ANKARA.

Nice puzzle. But, seems to me 99% of puzzles have this exact theme structure. It‚Äôs always a somewhat eye-rolling pun, based on some long-entry-starters. Can there really not be more variety in something that‚Äôs published *every single day*?

Good Wed. puzzle.  Played on the faster side for me.

Had to run the alphabet to get the "C" in NSC/CANO.  When that didn't work, I guessed correctly that ABC was wrong and the proper network is NBC (which of course makes sense now that I think about it).  Ran the alphabet again and got the solve.

Didn't know SEURAT or INGENUE but didn't even notice thanks to crosses.

Back in the late 90s, my husband had a small side job where he was helping SKYMALL put their products up for sale on their brand-new website.  Nobody was quite certain if consumers would actually buy products on the Internet.
Everyone in this comments section is far too humble. I requested BRAGGING about special TALENTS

29A made me tear up. In our house, the lead-up to Blanket Approval went like this:

The Dog (RiP, sweet girl): ‚ÄúMnnhhh‚Ä¶‚Äù
Me: ‚ÄúHoney, The Dog wants to be invited on the plaid blanket, preferably somewhere right near the top of your head.‚Äù
Hubby [decisively; manly-like]: ‚ÄúNo! I just washed the plaid blanket. Again.‚Äù

The Dog: ‚ÄúNnnnhhhhnnNNNN‚Ä¶‚Äù
Me [reasonably]: ‚ÄúHoney. You like washing things. She likes lying on them. Preferably somewhere right near the top of your head.‚Äù
Hubby [still manly-like, but an octave higher]: ‚ÄúNo. If you two had your way, there wouldn‚Äôt be a square inch of surface free of dog hair in the entire house. I‚Äôm using the plaid blanket tonight.‚Äù

The Dog: ‚ÄúNhmPHH‚Ä¶‚Äù
Me [employing eyelash-BATTING PRACTICE]: ‚ÄúHoney.‚Äù
Hubby [plaintively now]: ‚ÄúNooo, you girls get your own blanket.‚Äù

The Dog: ‚ÄúNhmPHMPHH!‚Äù

An almost imperceptible tap signaling BLANKET APPROVAL. 

Curtain.
I love Stephen FRY and so knew for sure that was the correct answer for the V for Vendetta clue. That probably added a good couple minutes to my time.
A very Wednesday puzzle!   A couple stumbles to start but it came together like one of grandma‚Äôs quilts!
TIL there are two actors in "V for Vendetta" named Stephen with a three-letter last name. Clever cluing!
CANO-CANOE lol
Actually easier than the Tuesday puzzle for those who want to know such things. Nice satisfying solve.
The top middle took me twice as long as the rest of the puzzle. ETUDE, SICEM, INGENUE, SEURAT, yikes

bet most of you didn't know that JoCo wrote a song about SKYMALL, that five-mile-high mall... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l0Cv-7lcAO8 Solve was faster than my average, but that's PAR for the course these days. I thought NSC/CANO and ABA/SEAEEL were tougher than I expect on a Wednesday.

a few good earworms today, but we'll start with Barbara Cook at Carnegie Hall singing The Ingenue. For those who don't know, she created the role of Marian Paroo in THE MUSIC MAN opposite Robert Preston. They both won Tonys, but her movie role went to... well, it's in the lyric. https://youtu.be/utikSv0I3zQ
Perhaps true Quilting Bees are not competitive, but Quilting classes often are.
As a quilter, I was thrilled with today‚Äôs puzzle!

Once, just once, I'd like [Week-ending exclamation] solve to
OGYMIOF


Oh God, you mean it's only Friday? :-(

The photo at the top of the page reminds me of Maxfield Parrish's Contentment. In the painting, the women are facing the other way and looking at each other longingly. But it's the first thing that sprang to mind when I saw the photo.

For several years I taught at Wofford College in Spartanburg, SC, where the mascot is the Boston Terrier.
Our opponents sometimes laughed at our mascot, but most of the time, by the end of the game, they weren't laughing anymore.

My local City PS 40 had a quilter who encouraged us to make quilt squares to remember those lost on 9/11.  I quilted with daughters a fire fighter's boots using part of a uniform and another one with a rainbow smbolizing hope. It hang in a upper hallway.  The community had a spelling be- parents of the students did the quilting!
Easier than I had anticipated at the start.  Thank you.  Very enjoyable.

Help! I know I'm a luddite but I print out the crossword ("Newspaper Version") Thurs-Sun. Something has occurred and no device will let me print it actual size and centered on the page so that I can see the left side of the clues. This has happened before in the past. I presume someone at the Times has changed the print format. In the past some devices still let me print (at least to pdf) but not this time. Can anyone fix this? No printer setting change will fix it on my end.

A delightful solve. Thanks Joe Deeney. 
I thought I had finished, but got the ‚Äúkeep trying‚Äù message and then had to search for my mistake. Finally found it in the top right corner where I had tibula and not FIBULA. Knowing absolutely nothing about Programming, I thought ‚ÄúItS‚Äù made as much sense as anything. But of course when I saw IFS emerge I could see that made much more sense.

I'm a world record video game speedrunner! Does that count? 

Also to your Tay Tay question, I've heard it only from my boss, a grandmother who became a Swiftie in big part because of her granddaughters. I love it. 

Great puzzle, Joe!
Loved SEAELL as an answer.  Is there any other answer (other than yesterdays WOOOO...OOOW) that has that many vowels in a row?  Sequoia I always thought held the record.

Hi! I don‚Äôt want to say which famous name I did not know in case they are tracking their mentions in the crossword puzzle, but that got me! I enjoyed the puzzle as almost always. Glad to have Sam Ezersoy back, too although Joel was great
as well!
I thought "good for an angler, bad for a dog trainer" was pretty cute.
I believe a quilting bee is a gathering at which participants sit around a large table or quilt press working on the same quilt and enjoying each other's company.

Rather underwhelmed.

The theme went over my head, and felt especially forced. Crossing 3 proper nouns EMILE, IVAN IV and anago and an obscure acronym ABA is a Natick, as is crossing 2 acronyms NSC and NBC. Literally no one says terrif  for FAB. Finally, the crossing of CANO with CANOE just feels lazy.

Overall, too much clunky full, crossowrdese proper names and trivia to force fit the theme made this not very fun.

@Jo yeah, I had to run the alphabet to fill that one as my last square - I wouldn‚Äôt have thought of the NSC (but it‚Äôs a perfectly fine clue). Everything else was easy or totally on my wavelength (like SEURAT, which was a gimme for me but might be tough for others). Very close to a personal best.

@Jeb Jones 
I also ran the alphabet here when I didn't get the music.

@Steve L 

For a Polish person the flexibility of English, and especially American English, when it comes to names and surnames is quite amazing.

In the Polish language and in Polish culture surnames just don't work as first names. Jan Kowalski, Barbara Nowak, Ewelina Kwiatkowska, Stefan Lewicki (that one is a nod to you, Steve L)  - all those first name/surname combinations are typical for Poland. But Kwiatkowska Ewelina, Lewicki Stefan or Nowak Kowalski just would not fly.

Also, in official contexts we sometimes say our surname first and first name second - can you imagine the confusion if first names and surnames were interchangable under such circumstances? ü§£

I like how Americans handle it, but having a similar freedom in picking names over here would require surprisingly big changes of how we do things. Interesting.

@Andrzej 

In the past 20-30 years, there has been a drastic uptick in the number of kids being named with a traditional last name as a first name.  Many of these derive from professions.  One of our biggest cultural phenomena is an example of that--Taylor Swift.  Not to be overlooked, Beyonce's name is derived from a last name on her mother's side.

So many kids now are being named Tyler, Parker, Carter, Walker, Harper,  Grayson, and Mason, along with the traditional Olivias, Noahs, Emmas, Olivers and Sophias.

However:

Robinson CANO is not American.  He's from the Dominican Republic.  This habit is not that prevalent there, although they do have a habit of creative naming of their own...often obscure saints and classical names, like Isis and Osiris, and many just made up for the occasion.  (Based on decades of working with literally thousands of Dominican kids, I can provide first-hand information.)  To use someone specific's last name as a first name is actually quite rare over there, and is quite the honor to bestow on the original owner of the name.

And besides, "Jackie" didn't fit that well into Spanish phonology.

@Jo 
This thread is way tmi

@nash.mark 

Sorry. Wrong thread. See next thread

@Mike 

For our non-baseball fans out there:

A WALK is a free pass to FIRST base that a batter earns when the pitcher throws four pitches that are not in the strike zone and which the batter doesn't swing at.  The strike zone is an imaginary rectangle formed by the width of home plate and the height of the area between the batter's knees and the midpoint of their torso.

There are situations where it is strategic to the defensive team to intentionally give the batter FIRST base (one such case may be that the next batter is considered an easy out).  Thanks to a recent rule change, the defensive team can just motion the batter to first base.  (This is called an intentional walk.)

But usually, pitchers try to avoid issuing walks, as they statistically tend to increase the batting team's chance of scoring dramatically.

@Steve L 

I read your explanation but I can't say I understand it. I can see you out a lot of effort into making it as approachable as possible but for me the terminology is just too alien. Also, you probably don't realize the level of ignorance of somebody who has never experienced baseball. When I imagine a baseball field with all of the people on it, I don't even know who is playing for which team. The pitcher and the batter (this is the first time in my life that I actually used those words btw) are from opposing teams, right?

@Steve L 

One more thing for now, please! If I take baby steps with this - two at a time, say - maybe I will rememebr this stuff in the end. So... The guys who run from base to base (and who score when they complete the circuit?) - they are on the batter's or pitcher's team? (Ok so it was two more things)

@Andrzej 
I know very little about baseball, but maybe I can clarify a couple of things for you. All the players you see on the field, including the pitcher, are from the same team (call them Team A). The opposing team (B) comes up to bat, one by one, with a goal of hitting the ball and getting to base before Team A can retrieve the ball and ‚Äútag‚Äù the B player with it. There are 4 bases, numbered counterclockwise, that the player must traverse (in order) before scoring a run. Getting to a base without being tagged means safety. The number of bases a player can run depends on how far they hit the ball and how fast the opposing team can retrieve it.

The batter can also get to first base without actually hitting the ball. This is known as a ‚Äúwalk‚Äù and it‚Äôs awarded to the batter when the pitcher doesn‚Äôt throw the ball properly. Once a player gets safely to a base, they wait for the next batter to hit the ball, and run while that ball is being retrieved.

At the end of the inning, the teams switch positions and Team A takes their turn at hitting the ball and running the bases, while Team B works the field.

I hope this helps. I‚Äôm sure others will correct me if I got something wrong.

@Andrzej 

Base runners are on the batter‚Äôs team. Being on base is a result of a successful turn at bat; most commonly, because they got a hit.

@Steve L 
Thanks. I was wondering why a player would WALK rather than run.
There is a very vague similarity to the game of rounders we used to play on the street when I was a child (before parked cars), played with an old tennis racquet and even older tennis ball. There could be 15-20 players on each side. Baseball bats completely unknown.
If the bowler/pitcher threw the ball really badly, the batter had 2 choices - do nothing or run to the first base (someone's jumper/sweater). You got 3 turns at trying to hit the ball. On the third miss you had to run anyway. We were all about age 10-11 or under, so not good at hitting balls.
But if the ball was hit a good distance, you kept on running round and round!
A main rule was the batter had to drop the bat before running, because there was only one bat.

For those who have absolutely no idea about how baseball is played, and want to get a quick idea in about 3 minutes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=daiZtbGFdDM Once you've watched that and understood it, you might follow it up with this 5-minute video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JHGMLEF7QK4 Other videos are out there, but I think that a total beginner would get too confused with some of the longer but more thorough videos. Next, I'd suggest watching part or all of an actual baseball game, of which there are many out there on YouTube. Here is a good example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gMm3EODDb6w This is the first game of last year's World Series between the New York Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers. I'd suggest watching just the dramatic 10th inning (starting at 1:52:52 through about 2:13). You can get a great feel for how baseball is played and can be exciting, even if you don't understand everything. Hope you enjoy!

@Hardroch 

More importantly to the global picture, baseball is the number one sport in many Latin American countries, number two after soccer in some others, and also number one or quite popular in Japan, South Korea and other Far Eastern countries.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

The similarity exists because about 200 years ago, baseball developed from rounders.  In the US, there's another variation for children, kickball, where a larger ball (volleyball-sized) is kicked instead of batted, but the other rules are similar to baseball rules.

@Hardroch 

I've lived in Europe for all my 44+ years and I can't recall ever seeing a baseball field in real life (and I've been on countless castle and church towers, mountains and other tall landmarks. Almost always there is a football field in sight, sometimes many of them, but baseball?) or any mention of baseball in the sports section of the news (I haven't watched TV news in 10 or 15 years but earlier I did it daily since I was a child). I've met professional and amateur sports people of different sports, but never baseball.

Is baseball international? Apparently it is. But over here - in Europe and certainly in Poland - it is a marginal phenomenon. 

Last time I checked when this came up last year there were 8 baseball fields in Poland (a country of some 40 000 000 people, including migrants), none of them in a big city, and Warsaw's closest one was 120 km away (a long distance in Polish terms) in a provincial city few people visit.

There's a crossword analog to PAR at xwstats.com, where average times are given based on the stats of their members. But like golf's PAR, the number is still useful to determine the relative difficulty of the puzzle.

It's also interesting that a SUBPAR performance in any endeavor is below average, and yet a duffer's poor golf score is actually ABOVE PAR.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday puzzle from January 18, 1998 by Ed Early and Bob Klahn with the title "Prophecy." Will note that January 18 would have been the day before MLK day that year. The first theme answer was clued as: "Part 1 of a prophecy by Martin Luther King Jr." And all the rest were clued as "Part 2," "Part 3," etc. The theme answers (with length): IHAVEADREAMTHATONEDAYON (23) THEREDHILLSOFGEORGIATHE (23) SONSOFFORMERSLAVESAND (21) THESONSOF (9) FORMERSLAVEOWNERSWILL (21) BEABLETOSITDOWNTOGETHER (23) ATTHETABLEOFBROTHERHOOD (23) All of those theme answers appeared for the first and only time in any puzzle. And he managed to do that without any weird down crossing answers. That's just... amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/18/1998&g=37&d=A I'm done. ....

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade

@Mean Old Lady

I think of a quilting bee as something from the days of yore, a group of quilters coming together to work on quilting a top made by one person thereby saving that person the tedium of quilting the entire quilt by themselves. Do you quilt everything yourself? Use a sewing machine?

@Mark 
There are multiple meanings for 'quilting bee.'
I have belonged to gulds and bees in Ohio, Arkansas, and Mississippi, and I know quilters from many other states.  We all do our own quilting.  I have hand-quilted some of my quilts, but now that arthritis is part of my life, I quilt using my 'domestic machine.'  I have also paid hand- and "long-arm machine" quilters to do the quiilting.  (Then they hand the quilt back to me for the final steps of binding and adding a label and possibly a 'hanging sleeve.'  
A Mennonite quilter I know holds 'quilting bees' with a group working on a single quilt, but instead of stitching, the workers "tie" the quilt.  It is not as secure or thorough as actual quilting, but it's a lot faster....

@Mean Old Lady 

A Quilting Story 
(about a quilt that never did, and never will, cover a bed)

I worked for a senior living organization that began almost 125 years ago. It was the first one (and still the only) that catered to Jewish people in its state. The entire community came together to create and support this facility and it grew and was known for its excellence. 

Fast forward to, hm, I'm thinking the 1980s or '90s. It was decided that a community quilt that would celebrate the community would be created... I was not there, so I can't comment on a lot of the decisions that went into creating this amazing craft. 

But I loved to talk about it whenever I gave tours of the building, because this was an entirely created-by-hand quilt. Women from the community organizations all sat around this huge fabric, each working on their own organization's block, and sewing it together. Meanwhile, their children (who are now adults) were sitting beneath it. 
The children caught the needles as they went down, and sent them back up! 

I love to imagine the gossip those children heard, and what they learned, as that immense quilt was created! It is still there, having been removed while the building was renovated, but returned to its spot immediately after, and only removed for cleaning and repairs over the years. Guests love to stop and marvel at it as they walk by, and some share reminiscences of being "under the quilt." Oh, and there is a companion book w/ the story of each square.

@Mean Old Lady 

I agree, and although I know I'm probably wrong, I choose to believe it refers to the blanket stitch.

@Mean Old Lady 
I have a Mennonite tied quilt. It was my mother's, I think my grandmother made it. My mom had 10 children, so it went through a lot over the years.

Pretty are much all terriers were bred to hunt foxes and other small game, including the BORDERTERRIER. INT is for interception... in American football, it's when a pass/throw from the quarterback to one of their receivers is intercepted by the other team and they now have possession of the ball and can try to score. It's not good.  ;-)

SIC EM is a command for dogs to attack.

SKYMALL is/was an in-flight magazine that you could buy things from. They were at everyone's seat, so you could browse while you fly.

I know nothing of quilting terms but I also remembered ANKARA and BOSSES, the latter of which shocked me.  

Hope this helps a bit.  :-) 

SKYMALL

@HeathieJ 

Oh, is *that* what INT stands for-! I admit to out-loud kvetching about that (and a few other) clues today. 

But I was superbly happy with the clue for 1A! 

To me, the difference was a clever clue for which a bit of baseball/softball knowledge would be of an assist, versus a boringly straightforward clue requiring the abbreviation of a second-tier stat. Not to mention, INT could've been clued any number of ways (whereas RBI, for example, doesn't have other real-world examples).

But I digress! Thanks again HeathieJ for enlightening me!

@Jane Wheelaghan SIC 'EM is a phrase, with the colloquial 'em standing in for "them". Of course in the grid, there's no way to know any of that! Looking up the first word by itself results in a definition; the verb is what you're looking for: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sic
